title: Prognostic Scores in Oncology: Key Prognostic Score Types
summary: Comprehensive guide to major prognostic scoring systems in oncology, including disease-specific, organ-specific, and biomarker-integrated models.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Prognostic Scores in Oncology
Topic 2: Key Prognostic Score Types
1. Overview

Prognostic tools in oncology vary widely based on cancer type, disease stage, and available diagnostics. They serve to stratify patient risk, guide treatment intensity, and support shared decision-making.
Modern scores range from simple clinical indices to genomically integrated models. They help predict outcomes such as:
Prognostic scores should be interpreted in clinical context - they inform but don't dictate treatment decisions.
2. Disease-Specific Scoring Systems
These tools integrate tumor biology, staging, and patient-specific variables to inform care. Common examples include:

rows: Age, LDH, ECOG performance status, Ann Arbor stage, extranodal involvement
Age > 60, Ann Arbor stage III-IV, hemoglobin < 12 g/dL, >4 nodal areas, LDH
β2-microglobulin, albumin, high-risk cytogenetics (e.g., del(17p), t(4;14)), LDH
Hemoglobin, ANC, platelets, % marrow blasts, cytogenetics, transfusion dependence
Age ≥45, stage IV, male sex, low albumin, low hemoglobin, high WBC, low lymphocytes

content.text: These scores often form the basis of treatment algorithms and influence trial eligibility.

3. Organ-Specific Prognostic Models
Used where organ function strongly influences prognosis, especially in primary or metastatic cancers affecting the liver, brain, or kidneys.

rows: Liver function; influences resection, transplant candidacy
Combines tumor stage, liver function, PS to guide therapy
Helps select patients for surgery or radiosurgery

content.text: 3.1 Child-Pugh Score Components
Classification: A (5-6 points), B (7-9 points), C (10-15 points)
4. Biomarker-Integrated Scores
These tools integrate molecular and genomic data to refine risk. They are often validated to guide adjuvant therapy or surveillance.

rows: Assesses benefit of chemotherapy vs. endocrine therapy
Detects minimal residual disease, early relapse
Prognostic and predictive for immune checkpoint therapy

content.text: Circulating biomarkers (e.g., ctDNA) are gaining traction in dynamic prognosis post-surgery or therapy.

5. Frailty and Functional Assessment Scores
Although not traditional prognostic tools, these significantly impact outcomes in older and comorbid patients.

rows: Used in ICU triage, oncology, and surgical planning

content.text: Increasingly, these are used in combination with cancer-specific scores to personalize treatment.
5.1 G8 Screening Tool Components

items: Has food intake declined due to loss of appetite, digestive problems, chewing or swallowing difficulties?

content.text: Score ≤14 suggests frailty requiring comprehensive geriatric assessment.
6. Composite and AI-Driven Models
Newer approaches involve nomograms or machine learning algorithms built from real-world and trial datasets.

items: MSKCC nomograms: Available for breast, prostate, and sarcoma; combine multiple clinical/pathologic factors
AI algorithms: Integrate EHR data, imaging, and genomics for individualized prognostication
Radiomics and deep learning: Under evaluation to predict outcomes based on imaging phenotypes

content.text: 7. Clinical Use Case Mapping

rows: CGA + G8 or CFS + disease-specific score
Age-adapted scores + Lansky + tumor type-specific models
ECOG + organ scores (e.g., Child-Pugh) + frailty assessment
Trial-specific stratification using PS + molecular markers

content.text: 8. Summary
Prognostic scoring in oncology is evolving to reflect a multidimensional understanding of disease biology, host factors, and treatment context. Key principles include:

items: No one-size-fits-all: Choose tools based on disease, age, and treatment goals.
Combine functional, biochemical, and molecular insights.
Use scores to communicate prognosis, guide therapy, and identify trial candidates.
Stay updated as AI-based models and liquid biomarkers reshape the prognostic landscape.

content.text: Key Takeaways

items: Disease-specific scores (IPI, R-ISS) remain fundamental for treatment planning
Organ function scores (Child-Pugh, MELD) are critical for hepatic malignancies
Molecular tools (Oncotype, ctDNA) add precision to risk stratification
Frailty assessments (G8, CFS) are essential in geriatric oncology
Emerging AI models may integrate all these dimensions in the future
